title: 114_s2896
content: The "Care Veterans Deserve Act of 2016" expands the Veterans Choice Program. The "Care Veterans Deserve Act of 2016" eliminates the sunset provision and expands eligibility for the Veterans Choice Program. The "Care Veterans Deserve Act of 2016" expands eligibility for the Veterans Choice Program by amending subsection (b) to include veterans enrolled in the system of annual patient enrollment under section 1705 of title 38, United States Code. Conforming amendments are made to subsection (c)(1) to remove specific references to eligible veterans described in subsection (b)(2)(A). The Care Veterans Deserve Act of 2016 amends subsections to provide information on the availability of care and services under the Veterans Health Administration to enrolled veterans. The Care Veterans Deserve Act of 2016 requires the Secretary to provide information on care and services to veterans within 120 days of enactment. Subsection (p)(2)(A) is amended to remove certain language. The Care Veterans Deserve Act of 2016 requires the Secretary to provide information on care and services to veterans within 120 days of enactment. Subsection (p)(2)(A) is amended to remove certain language. Access of veterans to walk-in clinics is addressed in Section 3. The Care Veterans Deserve Act of 2016 mandates the Secretary to contract with a national chain of walk-in clinics to offer hospital care and medical services to enrolled veterans without requiring authorization or copayments. The Secretary may not require a national chain of walk-in clinics to expand locations as a condition of a contract. The clinics must transmit weekly information to the Secretary on hospital care and medical services provided to veterans. Information must be securely transmitted to veterans' electronic health records. The Secretary cannot mandate a national chain of walk-in clinics to expand locations for a contract. Clinics must transmit weekly information on care provided to veterans, but this is not required for payment. SEC. 4. Licensure of health care professionals at the Department of Veterans Affairs for telemedicine treatment. The new section 1730B allows covered health care professionals to practice via telemedicine across state lines without licensure restrictions, regardless of the location of the professional or patient. This applies even if the care is provided in a federal facility. The new section 1730B allows covered health care professionals to practice via telemedicine across state lines without licensure restrictions, even in federal facilities. This section does not affect obligations under the Controlled Substances Act. Covered health care professionals are defined as those authorized by the Secretary to provide care under this chapter and licensed in a State to practice their profession. The new section 1730B allows health care professionals to practice via telemedicine across state lines without licensure restrictions. Telemedicine is defined as using technology to provide health care when the patient and professional are geographically separated. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit a report on the effectiveness of telemedicine used by the Department of Veterans Affairs, including assessing veterans' and healthcare providers' satisfaction with the service. The report will assess the impact of telemedicine provided by the Department of Veterans Affairs on veterans' access to healthcare, frequency of telemedicine use, healthcare providers' productivity, appointment wait times, and the potential reduction in veterans' use of services at Department and non-Department facilities. The report will evaluate the effects of telemedicine by the Department of Veterans Affairs on veterans' healthcare access, appointment frequency, provider efficiency, wait times, and potential cost savings, including travel expenses, through the use of telemedicine. SEC. 5. Extension of operating hours for pharmacies and medical facilities of the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will extend pharmacy operating hours to include weekends and holidays, and until 8:00 p.m. on weekdays. Contracts will be made with providers for nights and weekends, and additional support staff may be hired as needed. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may arrange for a best-practices peer review by a nongovernmental hospital organization to evaluate the health care efficacy at each VA medical center, prioritizing those with long wait times or poor health outcomes.
